title: Will Bangladesh reap rewards despite not hosting ICC Women‚Äôs T20 World Cup?
description: Alison Mitchell is alongside Charu Sharma and Jim Maxwell to discuss the effects on women‚Äôs cricket in Bangladesh, with the country not hosting the Women‚Äôs ICC T20 World Cup. Bangladesh cricket writer Tawhid Qureshi gives his thoughts on how the domestic game in Bangladesh would have benefited from the spotlight that hosting a World Cup brings, and how Bangladeshi players need more pathways to the professional game.Ali, Jim & Charu reflect on Joe Root becoming England‚Äôs men‚Äôs leading run-scorer in Tests and on his compatriot Harry Brook scoring a triple century in the first Test in Multan against Pakistan.Plus, they find out more about cricket‚Äôs inventors and innovators by talking to Stuart Robertson ‚Äì the inventor of T20 cricket.
author: BBC World Service

title: Jason Gillespie on putting faith in his Pakistan players
description: Alison Mitchell is alongside Charu Sharma and Jim Maxwell to discuss Pakistan hosting England in a three-test series, which begins on 7 October.Alison speaks to Pakistan red-ball head coach Jason Gillespie ahead of the series with the new coach looking to turn around Pakistan‚Äôs fortunes, with just two wins in their last thirteen Tests. He talks about wanting to instill belief in his squad, as well as managing his captain Shan Masood and improving the squad‚Äôs fitness.Plus, Ali, Jim & Charu find out the origin of one of cricket‚Äôs iconic techniques - the ‚ÄòGoogly‚Äô.Photo Credit: Pakistan men's test team head coach Jason Gillespie speaks to the media at National Bank Cricket Stadium on July 07, 2024 in Karachi, Pakistan. (Photo by Muhammad Sameer Ali/Getty Images).

title: Leach leads England to magnificent Multan victory
description: Jonathan Agnew is alongside Steven Finn & Aatif Nawaz for reaction to England‚Äôs victory in the first Test against Pakistan at Multan. They discuss whether Ben Stokes will return for the second Test in the series and how Pakistan let England back into the game from a strong position . Hear from the captains, Ollie Pope and Shan Masood, as well as debutant Brydon Carse who took four wickets for England.

title: Brook goes big as England close in on victory
description: Jonathan Agnew is joined by Steven Finn and Andy Zaltzman to review another unforgettable day in Multan, where England posted the fourth highest Test score ever. You‚Äôll hear from England triple centurion Harry Brook and double centurion Joe Root, who, together, put on England‚Äôs highest ever partnership in Tests. You‚Äôll also hear from one of Brook‚Äôs childhood coaches, who takes us back to when he first picked up a bat!

title: Australia thrash Pakistan but suffer injury blows in Women‚Äôs T20 World Cup
description: Vlaeminck dislocates her shoulder and Healy limps offAustralia won by nine wickets to all but seal last-four spotAustralia have all but cemented their place in the T20 World Cup semi-finals yet their nine-wicket cakewalk against Pakistan has come at a cost with major injury concerns over their captain, Alyssa Healy, and luckless bowler Tayla Vlaeminck.Healy limped out with a calf problem, stricken when taking a swift second run while leading her side during what had appeared a trouble free chase after they had skittled Pakistan for just 82 in Dubai on Friday. title: England‚Äôs slow horse Jack Leach comes in from the cold to deliver again | James Wallace
description: Luckless spinner proves his enduring worth once more by playing a pivotal role in sensational victory over Pakistan‚ÄúBlimey, Beef. Who writes your scripts?‚Äù Graham Gooch famously trilled to Ian Botham while the meaty and mulleted all-rounder was busy dispatching the then record for Test dismissals in August 1986. Returning after a 63-day suspension for admitting cannabis use to play New Zealand at the Oval, Botham memorably took a wicket with his first ball back to draw level with the record and then went past it in his next over by pinning Jeff Crowe lbw. Gooch was left to wonder aloud about whether some ballpoint-wielding higher power might be responsible.‚ÄúYou couldn‚Äôt write a script like it‚Äù is one of sport‚Äôs most hackneyed phrases, of course. If Hollywood can come up with aliens bursting out of John Hurt‚Äôs stomach in outer space, then I‚Äôm pretty sure they‚Äôd be able to summon the creativity to imagine Bruce Edgar tickling a back-of-a-length delivery to second slip in south London. Continue reading...
author: James Wallace
